I don't think we are likely to see a determination by the supreme court on this issue in our life time. The reason for this is simple: I don;t think either side really wants to see it. ON the one side, you have the liberals whose best defense to the second amendment seems to be the collective rights theory. While this is an interesting theory, it is unlikely to hold up to supreme court scrutiny which traditionally has relied heavily on original intent in deciding constitutional issues. There have even been rulings by the supreme court that original intent is the only valid criteria when deciding constitutional cases. Given the vast amount of literature we have from the original framers of the constitution that clearly lay out their intent in the second amendment, the collective rights argument is not likely to prevail.
 
 Then you have a situation where it is confirmed that the Second Amendment does in fact convey an individual right, which SHALL NOT BE INFRINGED. This leads to a rather sticky situation. Background checks would, of course, be illegal since you cannot attach a prerequesit to the practice of a right. You also end up with some rather delicate issues insofar as exactly what types of limits you COULD impose before infringement begins. Concealed acrry laws would most certainly be an infringement, as would the NFA, which requires a $200 conditional tax stamp in order to own a machine gun. 
 
 This also brings another interesting question. At exactly what point does your individual right to bear arms end? Since the original intent of the founding fathers was without question to ensure that people be armed with the latest military style weapons, the posession of rocket launchers, hand grenades, gatling guns and anti tank rockets would obviously be covered by this individual right.  I would agree that common sense gun control laws are a good idea. I disagree as to what can be considered "common sense gun control". IMO, in order to constitute "common sense gun control", a law needs to meet the following criteria:
 
 1. It should address a recognised problem
 2. It should be enforcable
 3. It should not infringe on constitutional rights
 3. The costs associated with administration/enforcement should not outweigh the benifits 
 
 To the best of my knowledge, we have not in the history of this country had any problems associated with guns being legally used either in schools or on airplanes. An airplane is private property, thus the decision to allow or deny the carrying of weapons should lie with the owner of the airplane, not with the federal government. WHen guns were commonly carried on airplanes, there was never an incident of hijacking. The first hijacking was commited more than 10 years after guns were banned on aircraft. Realistically speaking, most airlines would be likely to continue banning weapons ont heir planes, so this is really a non issue.
 
 IT is also not within my knowledge that a shooting has ever taken place at a school where the individual involved was legally able to posess a gun. The law requires that you be over 18 in order to posess a rifle or shotgun, over 21 to posess a handgun. You further can not be a felon, can not be under a restraining order, can not have been convicted in a domestic violence case, and can not be mentaly defective. I don't think that any school shooting has ever occured where the individual has met all of those criteria. It seems foolish to me to ban posession of wepaons to people who meet all of those criteria, even if it is at a school. When that occasional deranged individual does come along who wants to shoot up a school, you have effectively removed one of the few tools that would be useful to stopping them. 
 
 As far as background checks go, we have had them for quite a while, and they do not seem to do a bit of good. There has been no decrease in violent crime that can be linked to background checks. They cost millions of dollars per year to administer, yet provide no real benifit. THe number of people that are turned down for gun purchase and are actually prevented from eventually purchasing a gun through a dealer are pretty low. Prosecutions for those who actually DO apply and attempt to purchase a weapon even though they are prohibited are incredibly rare. There is actaully a reason for this. In order for such a prosecution to be effective, the prosecutor would have to prove that the person attempted to purchase a weapon KNOWING that they were prohibited by law from doing so. 
 
 Do you see the problem here? A prosecutor would be stuck having to convince a jury that this individual walked into a gun store and filled out an application, with full knowledge that a background check would be performed, KNOWING that they were ineligeble to purchase a weapon. IT absolutly flies in the face of logic that anybody is going to walk into a gun store and incriminate themselves by filling out forms that they KNOW are going to be sent to the federal government wehn they are inelegible to purchase a firearm. IF you were a prosecutor, would you really want to take this in front of a jury? THere are also constitutional issues here. The supreme court has already ruled that you CANNOT charge a convicted felon with failing to register a weapon, as registering the wepon would be an act of self incrimination. IT would seem logical that basing prosecution on a form that an ineligeble person is required to fill out would fall under the same guidelines.
 
 I would agree that stricter penaltie for gun related crimes is a common sense gun control measure. Here in kansas, a burglar caught armed is automatically subject to a 5 year extension on their prison sentence. For years, we enjoyed a much lower rate of armed burglary than other states that do not have such laws. Recently, our rate of armed buglary is up (though stll much lower than many other states). I believe this is due to a change in recent judicial practice. While it used to be that the 5 year sentence for posession of the weapon generally ran consecutive to the sentece for breaking and entering (which was generally 5 years, for a total of 10 years), it has recently become common judicial practice to set the sentence to run concurrent to the sentence for breaking and entering, so the person only serves 5 years in total. 
 
 A similar situation exists in regards to our law that requires a stricter sentence for drug related crimes that involve the use or posession of a firearm. Prosecutors routinely plea bargain these cases down, and judges routinely reduce sentences in response to overfilled jails and overloaded court dockets. 
 
 While these types of programs are unquestionably effective in curbing criminal gun usage, the big question is are we willing to pay the price? Keeping people in jail for years is not a cheap proposition. I know that our local county jail rents beds to johnson county (the most populated county in KS, and the one with the highest crime rates). 95% of the prisoners are from johnson county. The next county over has a 315 bed jail which is full all the time, and 99% of their prisoners are farm outs from other counties (that county only has 3100 people in the whole county, and very low crime rates). They are getting ready to d an expansion and add ANOTHER 300 beds, and their research shows that they can expect them to be full all the time. One of the jails charges $35 per day per prisoner, the other charges $45 per day per prisoner. WE will average the two ad say it costs $0 per day, per prisoner to keep somebody in jail in kansas. This means that to tack 5 years onto a single persons sentence costs 73,000 dollars. 
 
 That money has to come from somewhere. Currently, KAnsas is (I think along with several other states) in a major budget crunch. They have resorted to collecting property taxes early and giving out income tax returns late to make up for this. Where are we going to come up with an extra $73,000 per prisoner over a 5 year period to pay for enforcement of these gun control laws?
 
 I am not saying thes types of laws are a bad idea, I think they are an excellent idea and I think they are much more likely to be effective than a lot of the other gun control laws that are currently in effect or have been proposed, but I think that we need to seriously look at such questions as how much it is going to cost and how to fund such things.

Secondly, I would love the opportunity to ensure that everone who purchases or comes into contact with a weapon knows how to properly and safely handle it. However, I would not trust the government to come up with the requirements for such regulation. I look at the TSA and the armed-pilots program, it is my understanding that the government is making this process very difficult for those that want to enroll. Many have said that the process is intrusive and insulting. It's not so hard for me to believe that if a process like this was necessary to purchase a firearm, then it would amount to the government intimidating people not to exercise their second amendment. I would love it if firearm safety were taught in schools, and at a relatively young age. It amazes me that those who advocate "gun safety" in lieu of gun control spend so little time promoting education, and so much time promoting storage methods that a) make the gun unavailable in an emergency, and b) likely just make the gun seem more mysterious and appealing to the same children we are keeping them away from. I think that the "do not touch" approach does have it's merits, but that should not be the only avenue taken. To me it's just like sex ed. Teaching abstinence is great, but when you only do that, people who don't choose abstinence should know that there are safe and unsafe ways to do things.
